FX

The DXY saw decent if not solid recovery from early lows below some key chart support levels to reclaim 89.500+ status, initially by virtue of weakness or rather a retracement in major counterparts, but also underpinned by some better than forecast US data (housing starts, permits and IP). However, the index really needs rebound firmly above 90.000 to mount a sustainable recovery and turn the tech outlook around from bearish. The Loonie maintains gains vs the Greenback, albeit a slender advantage on the back of stronger than expected Canadian manufacturing sales. USDCAD is hovering just below 1.2550 having briefly breached last Wednesday’s low (at 1.2540 vs 1.2545), with the next big event looming tomorrow in the form of the BoC policy meeting. No changes expected given ongoing NAFTA/global trade uncertainty, but with options indicating another hefty break-even of 120 pips and some hefty expiry interest lying between 1.2585-1.2600 in 2.1 bn. The biggest loser and underperformer, with USDCHF up to 0.9650+ while EURCHF extended its rally through 1.1900 to circa 1.1945 and close to the 1.2000 floor that was pulled by the SNB back in January 2015. Aside from any official intervention, Russia liquidating Swiss assets is still touted as a major factor. Another G10 laggard ahead with the Kiwi only just hovering around 0.7340 vs the USD and keeping tabs on 1.0600 vs the AUD ahead of Q1 CPI data on Wednesday that is seen mixed (firmer q/q, but weaker in y/y terms). Note, only a modest reaction and uptick on the latest GDT auction showing a 2.6% increase in prices and 0.6% rise in whole milk. Not quite architects of their own downfall but undermined by weak data and survey releases (UK labour/wages and German ZEW expectations respectively). Cable is struggling to retain 1.4300 having registered a new post-Brexit vote high and approaching 1.4400 barriers, while EURUSD is back above its 55 DMA at 1.2365 from 1.2400+ at one stage.

MARKET RECAP

US equity futures had a gradual, upward bias in pre-market trade, but struggled with resistance just beneath the 2700, keeping the S&P 500 Emini in a tight range between 2690 and 2700. As cash trading got underway, the Emini pushed ahead but quickly ran into the next hurdle ahead of 2710, and after failing to negotiate the level, backed-off and consolidated underneath 2710. In late trade, the Emini did breach 2710 to the upside. Despite earnings season now being underway, and a fair amount of equity-specific news, Emini volume levels remained subdued on Tuesday. And earnings dominated Tuesday’s session with Netflix (NFLX) outperforming the SPX and NDX, after it added subscribers beating the Street’s estimates. Toy names hampered the NDX (Hasbro (HAS) & Mattel (MAT)) which were among the worst performers as bankrupt Toys ‘R’ Us ruled-out an offer to keep some of its US and Canadian stores open. General Electric (GE) and UnitedHealth (UNH) were among top performers in the DJI, as GE is looking for opportunities in the bio technology field and looking to expand into medicine and cell therapies, as well as cancer treatments and vaccines. UNH boosted by a strong earnings report, beating both top and bottom line expectations and also raising guidance. On the negative side, Goldman Sachs (GS) at the bottom of the DJI despite a strong earnings report as well as decent trading revenue, GS initially opened higher but closed in the red as it halted its share repurchase programme. SPX +1.06% at 2706, NDX +2.12% at 6816, DJI +0.87% at 24786.

Amid thin volume on Tuesday, US Treasuries saw selling pressure at the short-end of the curve, which pushed 2yr yields up to fresh cyclical highs. However, the rest of the curve found buyers, particularly the long-end, where 30yr yields fell by c.3bps at settlement, and causing 2s30s to narrow to cyclical lows c.60bps. Most other major curves narrowed on the session with attention also on the 5s30s which was another that saw cyclical lows on Tuesday c.32bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 3 ticks higher at 120-18.

US MARKET WRAP
content:
US MARKET WRAP 17 April 2018: stocks crude up in thin trade; DXY up Tsys slightly higher

* SNAP-SHOT:  Stocks up, Treasuries up, DXY up, crude up

* REAR-VIEW: PBOC cuts RRR, lots of Fedspeak.

* AHEAD: BOC (Weds), UK/Eurozone/Aussie inflation (Weds), OPEC monitoring committee (Weds), US energy inventories (API after the bell, DOE data on Weds).

 

 

* GEOPOLITICS: Geopolitical risk continues to abate, though the war of words between Russia and the US continues. A slightly more positive development was the news that North and South Korea are discussing an announcement of a permanent end to military conflict. President Trump said the North and South “have my blessing” to end their war, adding that he hopes for a summit with Kim Jon Un, though it is possible it might not take place.

* TRADE WARS: NEC Director Kudlow on Tuesday said that the Chinese were offering a “constructive” tone with regards to trade disputes, and referring to Trump’s tweets on Monday, said that the President was not trying to engage in trade wars. Kudlow also said that the US continues to mull additional sanctions on Russia in response to the chemical weapons attack in Syria, contrary to some press reports on Monday. China is reported to be prepared and ready to start trade countermeasures against the US in response to earlier reports stating the US Trade Representative was gathering new trade complaint against Chinese high-tech services. China’s International Trade Representative will meet EU ambassadors to seek support over US protectionism. Elsewhere, after dodging being labelled an FX manipulator by the US, India has filed a WTO complaint against the US, demanding compensation for steel and aluminium tariffs (the EU and China have sought compensation for the same issue). In the context of NAFTA, Canadian government sources reported that the three nations are not in a position to say at this point that any more chapters have been closed or agreed on, warning that the meeting in Washington on Thursday is unlikely to provide any announcement.

* FED: Fed’s Williams (voter, hawk, soon to be NY Fed President) largely reiterated his monetary policy views, suggesting a course of gradual hikes is appropriate. Williams’ view on the US economy was positive, and sees inflation returning to target and the labour market continuing to strengthen. Williams sees the fed funds rate between 3%-4% by 2020 (Fed dots indicate 3.4%), and also sees wage pressure building and believes this will continue and sees productivity growth remaining low over the next 5-10 years. Elsewhere, Williams warned on the potential of negative impacts if a full-blown trade war were seen. Fed’s Bostic (voter, dove) is set to speak after hours. Fed’s Harker (non-voter, dovish) noted that labour market conditions are tight. Fed’s Evans (non-voter, dove) showed a slight tilt of tone by noting interest rates can be gradually raised without risk of a surge in inflation, which he sees moving towards the 2% target. He also added that global growth is picking up, although trade remains an uncertainty. The Fed’s discount rate minutes said regional Fed directors saw tight labour markets, rising wages, and solid economic conditions, with some noting uncertainty around the impact of US tax cuts.

* BOJ: In Japan, BOJ sources reported that the central bank will most likely stick with their forecast that inflation will hit 2% during the next FY in next week's quarterly review.

* PBOC: China’s PBoC cut its Required Reserve Ratio for some banks by 100bps as of April 25th; funds will be used to pay back medium-term lending facility to the PBoC, which said it will maintain prudent and neutral monetary policy. The operation will boost liquidity conditions by around CNY 400bln.

* ECB: In Europe, ECB’s Hansson (hawk) is confident on inflation developments.  

* DATA: US industrial production beat expectations (0.5% MM vs 0.3% exp), while manufacturing output was in line with expectations (+0.1% MM), mainly boosted by a rise in utilities output as the weather improved. Analysts said that, combined with survey evidence, the health of the manufacturing sector was positive, and the outlook is bright, though some warn that there are signs of peaking ahead. US housing starts and building permits both beat expectations, though analysts warn about volatility in the data, particularly in the multi-family sector. Global Dairy Trade price index rose 2.7%, and whole milk powder prices rose 0.9%, in line with what futures were indicating.

* EQUITIES: SPX +1.06% at 2706, NDX +2.12% at 6816, DJI +0.87% at 24786 // SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +1.64%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +0.47%, ENERGY (XLE): +0.78%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +0.40%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +0.88%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +1.03%, MATERIALS (XLB): +1.32%, TECH (XLK): +2.59%, TELECOMS (XTL): +0.24%, UTLITIES (XLU): +1.22%. US equity futures had a gradual, upward bias in pre-market trade, but struggled with resistance just beneath the 2700, keeping the S&P 500 Emini in a tight range between 2690 and 2700. As cash trading got underway, the Emini pushed ahead but quickly ran into the next hurdle ahead of 2710, and after failing to negotiate the level, backed-off and consolidated underneath 2710. In late trade, the Emini did breach 2710 to the upside. Despite earnings season now being underway, and a fair amount of equity-specific news, Emini volume levels remained subdued on Tuesday. And earnings dominated Tuesday’s session with Netflix (NFLX) outperforming the SPX and NDX, after it added subscribers beating the Street’s estimates. Toy names hampered the NDX (Hasbro (HAS) & Mattel (MAT)) which were among the worst performers as bankrupt Toys ‘R’ Us ruled-out an offer to keep some of its US and Canadian stores open. General Electric (GE) and UnitedHealth (UNH) were among top performers in the DJI, as GE is looking for opportunities in the bio technology field and looking to expand into medicine and cell therapies, as well as cancer treatments and vaccines. UNH boosted by a strong earnings report, beating both top and bottom line expectations and also raising guidance. On the negative side, Goldman Sachs (GS) at the bottom of the DJI despite a strong earnings report as well as decent trading revenue, GS initially opened higher but closed in the red as it halted its share repurchase programme.

*TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 3 ticks higher at 120-18. Amid thin volume on Tuesday, US Treasuries saw selling pressure at the short-end of the curve, which pushed 2yr yields up to fresh cyclical highs. However, the rest of the curve found buyers, particularly the long-end, where 30yr yields fell by c.3bps at settlement, and causing 2s30s to narrow to cyclical lows c.60bps. Most other major curves narrowed on the session with attention also on the 5s30s which was another that saw cyclical lows on Tuesday c.32bps.

 

* CRUDE: WTI future settles up 30 cents at USD 66.52, Brent futures settle up 16 cents at USD 71.58. Oil prices steadied on Tuesday as geopolitical fear in the Middle East faded, ahead of the Tuesday’s API weekly inventories release (expectations: crude -1.4mln, Cushing -1.2mln, gasoline -0.2mln, distillates -0.3mln). With that said, NEC Director Kudlow leaned against reports yesterday which suggested that the US had ruled-out further sanctions on Russia; Kudlow on Tuesday said that further sanctions remained under consideration. Traders are also awaiting tomorrow’s OPEC monitoring committee meeting where members are to discuss oil production cuts for 2019. News flow was limited to Russia's Energy Minister Novak stating that a bilateral deal on oil supplies between Russia and Iran could be extended for another five years, while traders continued to cite the positive comments from the Kuwaiti oil minister on Monday (who said that OPEC was considering a supply cut extension beyond 2018). While some question whether such a deal is necessary, others point to the threat from US shale, which is said to be more serious and persistent than OPEC had anticipated.

* FOREX: The DXY saw decent if not solid recovery from early lows below some key chart support levels to reclaim 89.500+ status, initially by virtue of weakness or rather a retracement in major counterparts, but also underpinned by some better than forecast US data (housing starts, permits and IP). However, the index really needs rebound firmly above 90.000 to mount a sustainable recovery and turn the tech outlook around from bearish. The Loonie maintains gains vs the Greenback, albeit a slender advantage on the back of stronger than expected Canadian manufacturing sales. USDCAD is hovering just below 1.2550 having briefly breached last Wednesday’s low (at 1.2540 vs 1.2545), with the next big event looming tomorrow in the form of the BoC policy meeting. No changes expected given ongoing NAFTA/global trade uncertainty, but with options indicating another hefty break-even of 120 pips and some hefty expiry interest lying between 1.2585-1.2600 in 2.1 bn. The biggest loser and underperformer, with USDCHF up to 0.9650+ while EURCHF extended its rally through 1.1900 to circa 1.1945 and close to the 1.2000 floor that was pulled by the SNB back in January 2015. Aside from any official intervention, Russia liquidating Swiss assets is still touted as a major factor. Another G10 laggard ahead with the Kiwi only just hovering around 0.7340 vs the USD and keeping tabs on 1.0600 vs the AUD ahead of Q1 CPI data on Wednesday that is seen mixed (firmer q/q, but weaker in y/y terms). Note, only a modest reaction and uptick on the latest GDT auction showing a 2.6% increase in prices and 0.6% rise in whole milk. Not quite architects of their own downfall but undermined by weak data and survey releases (UK labour/wages and German ZEW expectations respectively). Cable is struggling to retain 1.4300 having registered a new post-Brexit vote high and approaching 1.4400 barriers, while EURUSD is back above its 55 DMA at 1.2365 from 1.2400+ at one stage.

Another G10 laggard ahead with the Kiwi only just hovering above 0.7325 vs the Usd and keeping tabs on 1.0600 vs the Aud ahead of Q1 CPI data on Wednesday that is seen mixed (firmer q/q, but weaker in y/y terms). Note, only a modest reaction and uptick on the latest GDT auction showing a 2.6% increase in prices and 0.6% rise in whole milk.

GBP/EUR

Not quite architects of their own downfall, but undermined by weak data and survey releases (UK labour/wages and German ZEW expectations respectively). Cable is struggling to retain 1.4300 having registered a new post-Brexit vote high and approaching 1.4400 barriers, while Eur/Usd is testing its 55 DMA at 1.2336 from 1.2400+ at one stage.

EU DEBT LATEST: round trip completed for core bonds
content: It’s been gradual, but now full circle and a bit more for the EU benchmarks in terms of recovery from intraday lows. Bunds and Gilts have actually just carved out fresh session highs at 159.19 and 121.85 respectively (+4 and +8 ticks vs -20 and -29 ticks at worst). The turnaround began just ahead of UK data, but gathered pace thereafter and picked up a bit more momentum after an arguably even bleaker German ZEW survey, although global trade wars and Syria weighed on sentiment, and the latter at least has subsequently receded on the scale of major risk factors. Tech impulses may also have impacted as nearest downside chart supports held in again, around 158.92 and then 158.74-72 for Bunds, and at 121.44 (just). Ahead, some decent US data and plenty more Fed speak to potentially provide further direction.

subject: BofA Merrill Lynch April Fund Manager Survey highlights: bulls have been silenced but not routed
content:
• Average cash balance jumps 0.4% from 4.6% last month to 5.0% in April
  • Just 18% of investors surveyed think equities have already peaked; 40% expect a peak in the second half of 2018, while 39% think they won’t peak until 2019 or later
  • Allocation to equities falls to an 18-month low of net 29%, down from net 41% overweight in March
  • Expectations for faster global growth continue to fall, with net 5% expecting the global economy to be stronger in the next 12 months; this marks the lowest level since the UK voted to leave the EU in June 2016
  • The net percent of investors expecting profits to improve over the next 12 months fell to 18-month lows of just net 20%
  • Earnings expectations fell 12ppt to net 8%, substantially down from net 35% in February
  • The net percentage of investors who would like to see corporates improve their balance sheets remains at 8-year highs; a record net 33% think corporate balance sheets are overleveraged
  • While investors have been overweight Tech for more than a decade of FMS history, 64% of fund managers asked would move to underweight Tech if anti-trust, tax and privacy regulations ratcheted up
  • The threat of a trade war (38%) remains at the top of list of tail risks most commonly cited by investors, followed by a hawkish policy mistake by the Fed/ECB (22%) and concerns that the market structure will cause illiquidity (10%)
  • “Long FAANG+BAT” remains the most commonly cited crowded trade for the third straight month (33%); “Short USD” is second (21%), while “Long Corporate Bonds” comes in third (11%)
  • Higher inflation remains the consensus view, with net 82% of investors surveyed expecting core CPI to rise over the next 12 months

subject: DAILY US OPENING NEWS: EU bourses firmer on risk sentiment whilst Sterling strength sapped by poor data
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

17th April 2018

  • EU equities firmer on an improved risk sentiment
  • Cable falls on weaker than expected wage data
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US Building Permits, Housing Starts, Industrial Production, APIs, Fed’s Williams, Bostic,Quarles, Harker and Evans

 

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded with a somewhat indecisive tone after the positive momentum from Wall St waned as the region digested mixed tier-1 data releases from China including GDP. ASX 200 (+0.2%) saw mild gains amid a slew of corporate updates, while Nikkei 225 (Unch) was flat with price action contained by a firm JPY. Hang Seng (-0.83%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.4%) were choppy in reaction to the mixed data figures in which GDP Y/Y printed inline with estimates at 6.8% which surpasses the official target for 2018, while Q/Q printed slightly below estimates at 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.5%. Furthermore, Industrial Production also disappointed but was counterbalanced by solid growth in Retail Sales. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat amid a similar picture seen in riskier assets in Japan, while a 5yr JGB auction also failed to spur price action despite slightly firmer demand and higher prices, as this was in tandem with a lower amount sold.

PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.2771 (Prev. 6.2884)

PBoC offers CNY 367.5bln in 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility with the rate increased by 5bps to 3.30% (inline with increase in short-term rate in March and hikes in Reverse Repo rates)

Chinese GDP YY (Q1) 6.8% vs. Exp. 6.8% (Prev. 6.8%)

Chinese GDP QQ SA (Q1) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.6%)

Chinese Industrial Output YY (Mar) 6.0% vs. Exp. 6.3% (Prev. 6.2%)

Chinese Retail Sales YY (Mar) 10.1% vs. Exp. 9.7% (Prev. 9.4%)

Chinese Urban investment YTD YY (Mar) 7.5% vs. Exp. 7.7% (Prev. 7.9%)

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB's Hansson (Hawk) sees more confidence in inflation developments. (Newswires)

RBA Minutes says board agreed there was not a strong case for near term move in policy. Add, that given current conditions, board agreed next move in rates is likely to be upwards. Progress on inflation and unemployment is likely to be gradual. Strengthening AUD would slow expected pace of economy. Economy appeared likely to expand faster this year than the prior year. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

China is prepared and ready to start trade countermeasures; according to China Foreign Ministry spokeswoman. (Newswires)

US is said to be considering ways to retaliate against Chinese restrictions on US tech firms (WSJ)

Mexico Economy Minister Guajardo says 10 NAFTA chapters are already concluded or close to conclusion adds they are exploring a possible meeting with USTR Lighthizer on Thursday but is not expecting a major announcement regarding NAFTA on Thursday. (Newswires)

China diplomat warns that UK trade discussions with China would face significant uncertainties if UK fails to strike a Brexit deal with the EU. (Times)

Syrian TV reports that air defenses are responding to missiles over Syria's Homs and that there is an unidentified aircraft over Damascus. (Newswires)

North Korea and South Korea are reported to discuss announcing a permanent end to military conflict, according to press reports. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

  • German ZEW Economic Sentiment (Apr) -8.2 vs. Exp. -0.8 (Prev. 5.1)
  • German ZEW Current Conditions (Apr) 87.9 vs. Exp. 88.0 (Prev. 90.7)
  • UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Feb) 4.2% vs. Exp. 4.3% (Prev. 4.3%)
  • UK Claimant Count Unemployment Change (Mar) 11.6k vs. Exp. 5.0k (Prev. 9.2k, Rev. 15.1k)
  • UK Employment Change (Feb) 55k vs. Exp. 33k (Prev. 168k)
  • UK Avg Wk Earnings 3M YY (Feb) 2.8% vs. Exp. 3.0% (Prev. 2.8%)
  • UK Avg Earnings 3M YY (Ex-Bonus) (Feb) 2.8% vs. Exp. 2.8% (Prev. 2.6%)

EQUITIES

European equities have shown strength (Eurostoxx +0.3%) on the back of improved risk sentiment with Syrian tensions continuing to abate. This is most noted in the materials and IT sectors, with both leading their peers. Negativity is noted in consumer discretionary, led by Reckitt Benckiser (-2.6%) on a broker downgrade by Credit Suisse. Elsewhere, Chinese permission for foreign auto companies to set up more than two ventures has led to auto names strengthening with Daimler rising from EUR 65.24 to EUR 65.44 and BMW up from EUR 90.47 to EUR 91.10. GKN (2.2%) have been supported with Melrose expecting an offer to become unconditional by April 19th, AB food (+2.6%) are higher amid an earnings beat and Bayer (2.0%) have been lifted by the news that the co. has agreed to sell 3.6% of new shares to Singaporean state investment company Temasek for EUR 3bln; this comes as the company plans for a USD 62.5bln takeover of Monsanto.

FX

USD

The Usd remains under pressure, and the index slipped through chart support in the 89.355-325 area that houses a recent April low and rising channel, to expose 89.250 ahead of 89.000 and another major downside technical level around 88.942 (end of March base), before regaining a foothold on disappointing EU data.

EUR/GBP 

Still vying for top spot within the G10, as the cross remains in a broad 0.8650-00 range amidst decent buying interest between 0.8625-30, but both making further headway against the Greenback. Eur/Usd finally absorbed offers ahead of 1.2400 to trade above on stops (briefly), while Eur/Chf climbed to a fresh post-SNB floor removal peak just over 1.1900 as Usd/Chf hovers around 0.9600. Cable has also notched up a landmark after setting a new post-Brexit vote best around 1.4375 and now eyeing 1.4400 barrier resistance assuming no major set-back in wake of broadly softer than expected UK labour and earnings data – 1.4300 is holding in thus far.

JPY

Retreating from recent 107.00+ highs and pivoting around the big figure with daily chart support around 106.89 underpinning the pair vs hefty 1.5 bn option expiry interest at 107.20 that appears to be capping the upside.

AUD/NZD

Mixed Chinese data overnight and RBA minutes underlining the likelihood of no changes in rates for some time have weighed on the Aud, with 0.7800 vs the Usd rejected again, but the Kiwi has lost more ground vs its antipodean peer and the Usd as the cross rebounds further to touch 1.0600 and Nzd/Usd trades sub-0.7350. Note, a major bank favours a short from 0.7360.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds now consolidating off worst levels on a considerably weaker than expected German ZEW survey, especially in terms of the forward-looking expectations component, which is somewhat at odds with a 2018 GDP forecast upgrade from the major institutes, but more in keeping with a rise in recession risk to circa 30%. The 10 year debt future is back above 159.00 and only 7 ticks adrift vs -20 ticks at the low, while Gilts have also bounced from worst levels to 121.71 vs 121.48 (-29 ticks) on the sub-consensus UK jobs/wage data. Elsewhere, US Treasuries off overnight lows in tandem ahead of more data and a raft of Fed speakers.

COMMODITIES

Taking a look at the commodities complex, oil prices consolidated from the overnight gains with WTI (-0.1%) and Brent Crude (-0.1%) modestly lower on the day as concerns of supply disruptions in the Middle East temporarily fade, whilst rising US shale outputs is on traders’ minds ahead of the API weekly inventories later today. Moving onto the metals bloc, gold (-0.4%) prices have dipped lower, closer to the bottom of the range but losses are modest at best. Overnight, Chinese GDP printed in line at 6.8%, above the government’s target of around 6.5%. However, industrial output came short of the expected 6.3%, whilst daily steel output in March climbed to the highest level since September. In turn, Chinese iron ore futures extended losses and hit a 10-month low on concerns of a supply glut. On the flip side, London aluminium futures extend their rally to the highest level in almost seven years, buoyed by growing concerns that the aftermath of the US sanctions on major Russian producer Rusal will result in tighter supply conditions.

subject: PREVIEW: UK Labour Market Data at 0930BST (0430EDT)
content:
As has been the theme for many a month now, focus will be on the earnings figures, and the consensus looks for an uptick in the headline and ex-bonus figures from 2.8% to 3.0% and 2.6% to 2.8% respectively. Oxford Economics attributes the potential pick-up in wages to the fact that “pay growth saw a relatively soft period from December 2016 to February 2017 suggesting that base effects may push up wage inflation further.” HSBC are more optimistic and expect earnings to rise above 3% for the first time since September 2015, which should be enough to support a Bank of England rate hike in May despite the expected economic slowdown in Q1.

GBP has been rising against the USD for seven consecutive trading days and cable is at its highest level since the Brexit vote - back above 1.4300 – as the Brexit transition agreement reached last month has removed some of the economic uncertainty for business and individuals.

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling: weaker tone ahead of UK jobs and wage data
content: In similar vein to Bunds, the 10 year UK benchmark ran into topside offers and is now testing bids/support at the low end of early 121.48-81 Liffe trading parameters vs Monday’s 121.77 close, while its core German/Eurozone counterpart has extended losses to 20 ticks at a fresh 158.95 Eurex base. Aside from the overall bearish tone in bonds, UK debt appears to be front-running or hedging for upbeat data in the form of labour and earnings, and Short Sterling futures are also being dragged down in sympathy to 1-2 ticks below parity vs 1 tick above at one stage, while Cable is advancing further towards 1.4400 having surpassed its previous post-Brexit vote high.

subject: China is prepared and ready to start trade countermeasures; according to China Foreign Ministry spokeswoman
content: • This follows reports that the US Trade Representative is said to be putting together new trade complaint against China regarding high-tech services including cloud computing and is said to be considering tech-related actions under Section 301, while other reports noted that US is said to be considering ways to retaliate against Chinese restrictions on US tech firms

Snam (SRG IM) – An improved bid has been made by a Snam led consortium for a share in Greece’s Desfa grid, was for EUR 535mln. (Newswires)

Hochtief (HOT GY) / Cimic Group (CIM AU) – Cimic Group report a Q1 revenue of USD 3.2bln, as well as an NPAT of USD 172mln. Guidance has been confirmed for 2018. (Newswires)

Sanofi (SAN FP) – The co. and Advent International have entered into negotiations wherein Advent would acquire Zentiva, Sanofi’s EU generics business for EUR 1.9bln. The offer is firm, binding and fully financed. (Newswires)

Melrose (MRO LN) / GKN (GKN LN) – Melrose has received valid acceptances that represent approximately 81.80% of GKN voting rights. Melrose expects that the offer will become wholly unconditional by 19th April 2018. (Newswires)

Associated British Foods (ABF LN) - H1 Revenue GBP 7.42mln vs. exp. GBP 7.56mln. H1 EPS GBP 0.613, adj. operating profit GBP 648mln. Their full eyar outlook is unchanged, with progress expected on bot adj. opearting profit and adj. EPS. (Newswires)

Castellum (CAST SS) – Q1 profit from property management at SEK 665mln vs. Exp. SEK 640mln. Q1 rental income at SEK 1.27bln vs. Exp. 1.35bln. Q1 net income after tax for period at SEK 765mln. (Newswires)

AA (AA/ LN) – Trading EBITDA GBP 391mln vs. exp. GBP 390.8mln. Total DPS of GBP 0.05, comprising interim of GBP 0.036 already paid and a recommended final of GBP 0.014. Additional investments for growth resulting in lower FY19 EBITDA guidance of between GBP 335mln to GBP 345mln. (Newswires)

Ashmore Group (ASHM LN) – Co. says assets under management increased by USD 7.0bln during period, net inflows of USD 6.4bln and positive investment performance of USD 0.6bln. Co. says strongest quarter for gross and net flows since June 2013. (Newswires)

Anglo American (AAL LN) – Co. says value of rough diamond sales for De Beers’ third sales cycle of 2018 at USD 520mln. (Newswires)

Air France (AF FP) – Co. proposes a 7% wage increase in stages, the Union demands a 6% increase immediately. (Newswires)

VIVENDI (VIV FP) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OUTPERFORM AT EXANE BNP PARIBAS

LEG IMMOBILIEN (LEG GY) DOWNGRADED FROM BUY TO HOLD AT BANKHAUS

subject: Bunds: increasingly top heavy above 159.00
content: Rebounds appear more and more half-hearted, especially above the 159.00 handle in the absence of strong safe-haven demand or an alternative bullish catalyst as broad risk sentiment continues to improve or stabilise amidst an easing in global trade and geopolitical tensions (for now at least). Hence, the 10 year German bond has faded after an early attempt to the upside within a 159.17-03 range around yesterday’s 159.15 close, and looks prone to more selling pressure ahead of today’s German ZEW survey that may provide some underlying support (temporarily) if overly weak.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from HSBC, Bayer and Roche
content:
17th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded with a somewhat indecisive tone after the positive momentum from Wall St waned as the region digested mixed tier-1 data releases from China including GDP. ASX 200 (+0.3%) saw mild gains amid a slew of corporate updates, while Nikkei 225 (Unch) was flat with price action contained by a firm JPY. Hang Seng (Unch) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were choppy in reaction to the mixed data figures in which GDP Y/Y printed inline with estimates at 6.8% which surpasses the official target for 2018, while Q/Q printed slightly below estimates at 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.5%. Furthermore, Industrial Production also disappointed but was counterbalanced by solid growth in Retail Sales.

FTSE

HSBC (HSBA LN) - The co. has changed up their leadership and structure by combining UK and Swiss units of its private bank into a single entity, with a London based executive in charge. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Vectura (VEC LN) – Co. shares were seen higher by 11% yesterday with trading volume renewing speculation over a potential takeover of the Co. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

SAGE GROUP (SGE LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN

ASTRAZENECA (AZN LN) NAMED AS A PREFERRED EU PHARMA NAME BY CITI

RECKITT BENCKISER (RB/ LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) - The co. has agreed to sell a 3.6% of new shares to Singaporean state investment company Temasek for EUR 3bln. This is as the company plans for a USD 62.5bln takeover of Monsanto (MON). (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

BAYER (BAYN GY) NAMED AS A PREFERRED EU PHARMA NAME BY CITI

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Casino (CO FP) – 2018 Q1 sales at EUR 8.9bln. vs. Exp. 8.9bln. Co. reports +3.1% organic growth and +1.8% on comparable basis. Food retail sales posted a growth of +1.5% in France. Co. says strong dynamics is ongoing for the group. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) - The FDA has granted a designation of breakthrough therapy for Genentech's Hemlibra (Emicizumab-KXWH) in Hemophilia A without inhibitors. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

Sika (SIK SW) – Quarterly sales growth of 11% to CHF 1.554bln. Sales target of 7bln this year. Co. says EBIT and net profit should increase at a “disproportionately high rate” this year. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

NESTLE (NESN SW) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT BNP PARIBAS

PAN EUROPE

TomTom (TOM2 NA) – Q1 revenue of EUR 192mln vs. Prev. EUR 213mln. Q1 EBITDA EUR 44mln vs. Prev. EUR 34mln. Q1 adj. net income EUR 22.6mln vs. Prev. loss of EUR 7.0mln. Co. is reiterating guidance for 2018. (Newswires)

Altice (ATC NA) / Bouygues (EN FP) - Bouygues said that it is not in discussions with another operator, foregoing reports it wants to buy rival Altice. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) - The co. is holding a board meeting as requested by Italian market regulator Consob, that has asked the board members to provide information ahead of the April 24 shareholder meeting, according to sources. (Newswires)

Intesa Sanpaolo (ISP IM) / Intrum Justitia (INTRUM SS) - Intrum Justitia  has filed a binding bid for Intesa's debt collection unit in a EUR 3.6bln deal. This will rid Intesa of EUR 10.8bln of bad debt, with the Intesa board meeting on Tuesday for the deal. (Newswires)

Telefonica (TEF SM) – Co. are looking to raise USD 500mln – USD 1bln in an IPO of its Argentinian unit, according to sources. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PHILIPS (PHIA NA) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT DEUTSCHE BANK

COCA-COLA EUROPEAN PARTNERS (CCEP NA) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

JERONIMO MARTINS (JEM PL) UPGRADED TO HOLD BY HSBC

SCANDAVANIA

BROKER MOVES

TELIA (TELIA SS) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JP MORGAN

TELENOR (TEL NO) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JP MORGAN

US

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.8% at 2678, NDX +0.7% at 6675, DJI +0.9% at 24573

SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +0.75%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +1.01%, ENERGY (XLE): +1.01%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +0.47%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +0.8%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +1.00%, MATERIALS (XLB): +1.38%, TECH (XLK): +0.7%, TELECOMS (XTL): +1.49%, UTLITIES (XLU): +1.38%. Equity futures gapped higher at the open and traded sideways for most of the session. Action tended to focus around the 2680 region in ES, with the index struggling to hold onto gains above that level for the most part, trading between that level and the VWAP 2670 – 2675.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets traded with a somewhat indecisive tone amid mixed data releases from China
content:
• Asian equity markets traded with a somewhat indecisive tone amid mixed data releases from China
  • In FX, DXY below 89.50 with EUR/USD and GBP/USD holding onto recent gains, AUD hampered by RBA minutes
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK jobs, German ZEW, US Building Permits, Housing Starts, Industrial Production, APIs, Fed’s Williams, Quarles, Harker and Evans

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded with a somewhat indecisive tone after the positive momentum from Wall St waned as the region digested mixed tier-1 data releases from China including GDP. ASX 200 (+0.3%) saw mild gains amid a slew of corporate updates, while Nikkei 225 (Unch) was flat with price action contained by a firm JPY. Hang Seng (Unch) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were choppy in reaction to the mixed data figures in which GDP Y/Y printed inline with estimates at 6.8% which surpasses the official target for 2018, while Q/Q printed slightly below estimates at 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.5%. Furthermore, Industrial Production also disappointed but was counterbalanced by solid growth in Retail Sales. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat amid a similar picture seen in riskier assets in Japan, while a 5yr JGB auction also failed to spur price action despite slightly firmer demand and higher prices, as this was in tandem with a lower amount sold

Chinese GDP QQ SA (Q1) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.6%). (Newswires)
Chinese GDP YY (Q1) 6.8% vs. Exp. 6.8% (Prev. 6.8%)

Chinese Industrial Output YY (Mar) 6.0% vs. Exp. 6.3% (Prev. 6.2%)
Chinese Industrial Output YTD YY (Mar) 6.8% vs. Exp. 6.9% (Prev. 7.2%)

Chinese Retail Sales YY (Mar) 10.1% vs. Exp. 9.7% (Prev. 9.4%)
Chinese Retail Sales YTD YY (Mar) 9.8% vs. Exp. 9.7% (Prev. 9.7%)

US Trade Representative is said to be putting together new trade complaint against China regarding high-tech services including cloud computing and is said to be considering tech-related actions under Section 301, while other reports noted that US is said to be considering ways to retaliate against Chinese restrictions on US tech firms. (Newswires/WSJ)

China urged US to treat Chinese companies lawfully after the US banned Chinese telecoms firm ZTE from buying parts from US for 7 years due to illegally exporting US goods by the firm to Iran and North Korea. (Xinhua/Newswires)

PBoC skipped repo operations but instead offered CNY 367.5bln in 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility with the rate increased by 5bps to 3.30%. (Newswires)

UK

China diplomat warned that UK trade discussions with China would face significant uncertainties if UK fails to strike a Brexit deal with the EU. (Times)

EU

ECB’s Praet said ample degree of monetary policy remains necessary and that policy must be patient, persistent and prudent. Furthermore, Praet commented that the growth outlook confirms ECB's confidence. (Newswires)

European Union seeks talks with the US at the WTO over compensation for US steel and aluminium tariffs according to WTO filing. (Newswires)

Italian Treasury said to offer BTP maturing in November 2021 in exchange for up to five other bonds on Wednesday. (Newswires)

FX

USD languished after yesterday’s lost ground against its counterparts across the board with the DXY below 89.50. The subdued greenback ensured EUR/USD and GBP/USD held on to recent gains in which the latter posted its best levels since the 2016 Brexit referendum, while USD/JPY tested 107.00 to the downside. Elsewhere, AUD/USD was initially choppy after the RBA minutes mostly provided reiterations but then gradually declined as some suggested uncertainty regarding the outlook and after the Chinese data left much to be desired, while HKD remained near the weak point of the band despite further intervention by the HKMA which bought HKD 5.77bln in local currency during US hours to defend the peg.

RBA minutes from April 3rd meeting stated that the board agreed there was not a strong case for near term move in policy and that a strengthening AUD would slow expected pace of economy. The minutes also stated that given current conditions, the board agreed next move in rates is likely to be upwards but added that progress on inflation and unemployment is likely to be gradual. (Newswires)

Mexico Economy Minister Guajardo said 10 NAFTA chapters are already concluded or close to conclusion, while he also commented that he is exploring a possible meeting with USTR Lighthizer on Thursday but is not expecting a major announcement regarding NAFTA then. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES 

Commodity prices were mixed overnight in which WTI crude futures nursed the losses seen from the unwinding of geopolitical concerns, while the EIA also stated that US total shale oil production for May is seen higher by 125,000BPD at 6.996mln BPD (Prev. 118,000 BPD rise in April). Elsewhere, gold was rangebound amid a lacklustre greenback and indecisive risk tone, while copper was higher but with gains capped following mixed Chinese data.
GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump is said to halt plan for further Russian sanctions. (Washington Post)

Syrian TV reported that air defences responded to missile strike attempt on an airbase in Syria's Homs, which was later identified as a strike by Israel. (Newswires)

North Korea and South Korea are reported to discuss announcing a permanent end to military conflict, according to press reports. (Munhwa)

Treasuries were sold as European traders got to their desks on Monday morning, as some of the geopolitical risk eased. However, Treasuries did find buyers over the course of the session, particularly after a mixed retail sales report, as well as the latest business inventories and NAHB data, but the buying wasn’t enough to prevent the complex from settling slightly lower. The shape of the curve saw some modest flattening on Monday. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle half-a-tick lower at 120-15.

Fed’s Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) said he sees cyclical wage pressure building this year but added that he does not see inflation moving higher even though confident wage pressure will build up. Furthermore, Kaplan also stated he is very concerned that fiscal stimulus will turn into headwinds in 3-5 years. (Newswires)

US President Trump is to nominate PIMCO’s economist Richard Clarida as Fed Vice Chair. (Newswires)

UBS cut US Q1 GDP tracker to 1.7% (Prev. 1.8%) and Goldman Sachs cut US Q1 GDP tracker to 1.90% (Prev. 2.0%) after the retail sales data. (Newswires)

PREVIEW: RBA minutes from the April 3rd meeting where the central bank kept rates on hold at the record low of 1.50% as expected, due at 0230BST/2030CDT/0930HKT
content:
Today sees the release of the RBA’s minutes from the April 3rd meeting where the central bank held the Cash Rate Target at the record low of 1.50%. This was in-line with consensus as ASX 30 Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures had indicated a 100% expectation the central bank would keep policy unchanged.

At the meeting, the RBA reiterated that steady policy is consistent with growth and inflation goals, while it also repeated that a strengthening currency would result to slower pace of economic pick up. The central bank stated that inflation is likely to stay low for some time and that there is likely to be gradual progress on unemployment and inflation, while it further added that the pace of growth in wages seems to have troughed.

As a guide, there was sustained reaction seen in AUD/USD with the pair remaining near pre-announcement levels following the release as the comments from the central bank didn't provide anything new.
